Award.AwardTitle: International Research Fellowship Program: Does the Foliar Nitrogen Isoptope Variability in Rain Forest Trees Reflect Niche Partitioning, Biophysical Processes or Climate?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a 24-month research fellowship by Dr. Jordan Mayor to work with Dr. Benjamin Turner at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama.

The availability of nitrogen (N) to plants is a primary control over forest productivity and ecosystem dynamics throughout much of the world. Tropical forests are presumed to be relatively N-rich yet their growth and adaptations respond to natural and anthropogenic changes in N-cycling and climate. Due to the complexity of the N cycle and the various types of plant responses to N limitations, there is a strong research need to use the ratio of heavy to light stable isotope measurements of N to integrate both biogeochemical processes and plant community responses to fluctuations in N availability. However, to be confident in the use and interpretation of foliar N isotope ratios, underlying mechanistic processes must be better understood. The PI, while housed within the Soils Biogeochemistry laboratory of Dr. Benjamin Turner, will meet the above research need by measuring stable isotope ratios from all three forms of plant available soil N, along with tree root and leaf tissue, across three experimental systems throughout Panamanian rainforest. The experimental systems were selected to target the main hypothesized controls over plant N isotope values: precipitation, soil nutrient bioavailability, and the type of root-associated mycorrhizal fungi. Each of the three experimental systems is designed to target specific hypotheses and, when combined, provide for a unified theory on the causes of variability in tree N isotope patterns in tropical forests.

Human activities can increase N availability in ecosystems either by increasing N inputs through fertilizer addition or atmospheric deposition, or by speeding up internal recycling of N as a result of altered climate or landscape degradation. This joint research will inform the interpretation of relatively simple foliar analyses so that complex, time-integrated differences in N-cycles can be better understood and changes to them easily detected. In a time of rapid global change, these natural indexes will undoubtedly prove useful to forest monitoring efforts. In addition to the benefits of differentiating the underlying causes of tree N isotope ratios globally, these data will also permit testing for tree specialization on specific forms of soil N - a hypothesized mechanism for permitting the coexistence, rather than competitive exclusion, of otherwise similar tree species in biodiverse rainforest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported a Postdoctoral Researcher to conduct detailed research on the nitrogen cycle of rain forests in Panama. The postdoctoral researcher made use of an extensive array of long-term ecological research plots systems, as well as state of the art laboratory facilities, maintained by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. The nitrogen cycle of rain forests is complex with numerous forms that nitrogen can be found in, both mineral and organic, and multiple pathways from which it can both enter and leave an ecosystem. Studying the nitrogen cycle is important because despite it being in high concentrations in the atmosphere, it is often at such low bioavailable levels in the soil and as a result often limits the continued growth of forests.

Because of the complexity and importance of this mineral nutrient, it is imperative that sample collection, processing, and storage all be conducted in a timely manner. The facilities at STRI enabled for such care to be taken permitting the advanced study of the nitrogen cycle in forested ecosystems of Panama and particularly it allowed examination of a unique tracer of the nitrogen cycle – stable isotope ratios. Naturally occurring stable isotope ratios differ in a single neutron that affects the reaction rates of the nitrogen containing compounds as they chemically react or are transformed biologically. The heavier form, 15N, reacts slower and the ratio of the heavy to light isotopes, 15N:14N conveys information regarding the sources and pathways that nitrogen cycles in forested ecosystems. This project clarified specific sources of variability in ecosystem 15N;14N ratios allowing future scientists to more confidently use this metric to understand changes to nitrogen cycles brought about by climate change, disturbance, nitrogen deposition, or successional stages of forest maturation.

This postdoctoral research sampled extensively from the longest running fertilization experiment in lowland tropical forest, part of the Barro Colorado Natural Monument, and from a unique lower montane rainforest in the western mountains of Panama. The fertilization experiment was used to assess how experimentally altered nitrogen and phosphorus availability caused changes to the nitrogen cycle in soils and how this then alters the 15N:14N ratios of several locally common tree species. It was found that three of the four tree species all shifted their use of nitrogen to nitrate following nitrogen fertilization, the only soil nitrogen form that was elevated by nitrogen fertilization. These three tree species also stored more soil phosphorus in there leaves following phosphorus addition. A palm species was unable to switch its nitrogen use or to adjust it's leaf phosphorus for unknown reasons. Next, through a combination of experiments and natural surveys the role of several types of root symbiotic associations (mycorrhizae, nitrogen fixing bacteria, etc.) were examined to see if tropical tree and associated fungal 15N:14N ratios respond in a manner similar to higher-latitude forest ecosystems. In contrast to lowland forest, the montane species assemblages were shown to exhibit distinctive preferences for differing soil nitrogen forms suggesting that specialization on different nitrogen forms may facilitate species coexistence. Combined, the results of this project will aid in the formulation of a unified interpretation of nitrogen cycles and how they differ across biomes.

The postdoctoral research acted as a co-instructor of a field course offered to Panamanian college students, a mentor for a three month long student project on mycorrhizal infection, and was able to present research in three talks given in Panama and three talks given at professional meetings in the USA.
